dict.string: Abuse
What is Abuse?
"The LORD examines the righteous, but the wicked and those who love violence his soul hates". Psalm 11:5

God hates violence against His children. It is not ok for anyone to physically or emotionally harm another person.
Abuse takes on many forms and it can be from a parent, family member, another adult in the community OR it can also be from a boyfriend or girlfriend.
Physical abuse is when someone intentionally harms someone else physically. Examples include slapping, punching, shoving, kicking, burning, and biting. It can also include being confined for long periods of time (locked in a closet, tied up, etc.) Emotional abuse is using words and actions to make someone else feel bad, afraid, or controlled. Examples include being told they are "stupid" or "worthless", being threatened, and being isolated from other friends and family. This can be done in person or via texting and other technologies. Sexual abuse can include physical contact, such as inappropriate touching or rape, but other examples are making someone watch videos of others having sex or being forced to look at private body parts of another person. Neglect is when an adult fails to provide needed food, clothing, shelter, medical care, or supervision such that their child's health, safety, and well-being are threatened with harm.
If you are being abused it is not your fault and you are not alone. Pray that God would give you the courage, wisdom, and direction to seek help from a trusted adult.
How do I know if I am in an abusive marriage or dating relationship?
"Husbands, love your wives, just as Christ loved the church and gave himself up for her." Ephesians 5:25

Even though this verse is directed towards "husbands", it is an excellent example of how God wants us to treat each other in our relationships. Some people have actually tried to use the Bible to defend abusive behaviors against their spouse but abuse and control are not part of God's plan. How did Christ love the church? By serving others, washing their feet, loving and forgiving people, and ultimately dying for us all.

You might be in an abusive relationship if you experience any of the following: name calling, being made fun of, controlling behaviors, intimidation, isolation from friends and family, being physically hurt, or pressured or forced to have sex. Using the internet or texting to bully or hurt you and/or stalking you are other forms of abuse.
Put God first in your marriage and date life, begin praying for your relationships. Give God control and obey Him as He leads you. Seek help from a trusted believer in Christ. Seek counsel for your marriage if you suspect abuse. If you are dating an abusive person get out of the relationship. Go to the LINKS on this app to find websites that offer support for abuse.
Where is God?

"For he has not despised or disdained the suffering of the afflicted one; he has not hidden his face from him but has listened to his cry for help." Psalm 22:24-25 "I waited patiently for the LORD; he turned to me and heard my cry. He lifted me out of the slimy pit, out of the mud and mire; he set my feet on a rock and gave me a firm place to stand. He put a new song in my mouth, a hymn of praise to our God. Many will see and fear and put their trust in the LORD." Psalm 40:1-3
God is turning to you and hears your cry. He has not hidden His face. The Scriptures have given you a promise. Claim the promise and stand firm on the ROCK, the Lord.

When someone is being abused they often feel very much alone. It is important to know that God is always with you and He loves you. When you cry out to God, he hears you. He wants to be your stability and strength during this difficult time. Take comfort in his love and power and pray that he will protect you and help you. See the LINKS on this app for websites offering support for abuse.
What can I do if I am being abused?

"I call on you, O God, for you will answer me; give ear to me and hear my prayer. Show the wonder of your great love, you who save by your right hand those who take refuge in you from their foes. Keep me as the apple of your eye; hide me in the shadow of your wings." Psalm 17:6-13
God wants us to call out to him in our time of trouble and pain. You are the "apple of His eye" and he wants to be your refuge and protector.

It is tempting to keep information about abuse a secret. You might have been threatened to never tell anyone. You might be confused as you care for the person hurting you and do not want to see them get in trouble. However, abuse in any form is WRONG and it is important that you seek help.
See the Links on this app for websites offering support
How do I help friends that I think are being abused?
"When he lies, he speaks his native language, for he is a liar and the father of lies." John 8:44

Satan is the father of lies. He uses lies to prevent people from seeking help. Your friend might believe that the abuse is her or his fault. He or she might also believe that the person causing the abuse will change or that if they "behave" or act better they will not be abused anymore. Your friend might also be afraid to tell anyone about what has happened.

It is important that you help friends understand that it is NOT their fault, they can not do anything to change the behavior of the abuser, and they need to seek help from a trusted adult like a teacher, pastor, or school counselor. Also, be sure you speak the truth IN LOVE (Ephesians 4:15). You can hurt someone you are trying to help if you make them feel like they are stupid or at fault for "getting into" this situation. Pray for your friends by asking God to protect them, to rescue them, and to be their source of strength and peace during this difficult time. Seek help from another mature believer in Christ.
Religion
How is a person supposed to know which religion truly leads to God?

"----and the Scripture cannot be broken--" John 10:35
"Dear friends, do not believe every spirit, but test the spirits to see whether they are from God, because many false prophets have gone out into the world." 1 John 4:1
"We are from God, and whoever knows God listens to us; but whoever is not from God does not listen to us. This is how we recognize the Spirit of truth and the spirit of falsehood." 1 John 4:6

We are to test the spirits realizing that if a particular religion does not align with the scriptures, it is not the truth. Three key elements to consider when choosing a denomination: 1.Attitude Toward the Bible 2.Attitude Toward Christ 3.Attitude Toward Salvation

Every religion under the sun, whether pseudo-Christian or non-Christian that teaches man can do something to earn, or help to earn his own salvation is FALSE. Only true Biblical Christianity recognizes man as he really is, utterly lost in sin, destined for eternal separation from God. The gospel, "by which you are saved" is the glorious news that "Christ died for our sin" (I Corinthians 15:1,3), and that we can be saved by grace, through personal faith in Christ, plus nothing else whatever! Any religion which teaches otherwise is, to that extent, wrong.
What do Christians believe?

"For God did not send his Son into the world to condemn the world, but to save the world through him. Whoever believes in him is not condemned, but whoever does not believe stands condemned already because he has not believed in the name of God's one and only Son." John 3:17-18

Christians believe that God sent his only son to die and pay for their sins and who ever believes in Him will not die, but will have eternal life as it states in John 3:16. The only way to escape death is know Jesus Christ as Lord and Savior of your life recognizing you are a sinner in need of saving. See the "Saved" topic on this app for more information.

The Apostle`s Creed is a summation of the Christian beliefs spoken in many churches today which is founded on these main principles of Christianity: Belief in God the Father, Jesus Christ as the Son of God and the Holy Spirit The death, descent into hell, resurrection, and ascension of Christ The holiness of the Church and the communion of saints Christ's second coming, the Day of Judgment and salvation of the faithful
What does Jesus tell us about religion?

Then Jesus said to the crowds and to his disciples: "The teachers of the law and the Pharisees sit in Moses' seat. So you must obey them and do everything they tell you. But do not do what they do, for they do not practice what they preach. They tie up heavy loads and put them on men's shoulders, but they themselves are not willing to lift a finger to move them. Everything they do is done for men to see: They make their phylacteries wide and the tassels on their garments long; they love the place of honor at banquets and the most important seats in the synagogues; they love to be greeted in the marketplaces and to have men call them 'Rabbi.' But you are not to be called 'Rabbi,' for you have only one Master and you are all brothers. And do not call anyone on earth 'father,' for you have one Father, and he is in heaven. Nor are you to be called 'teacher,' for you have one Teacher, the Christ. The greatest among you will be your servant. For whoever exalts himself will be humbled, and whoever humbles himself will be exalted." Matthew 23:1-12

Jesus walked the earth some 2000 years ago. His life and ministry was very real, and was in accordance with God's perfect plan and will as foretold through the Prophets and Moses in the books of the Old Testament.
Jesus came and served so that all who come to Him as humble servants might have the abundant life leading to life eternal. Jesus teaches us religion in its most simple and perfect way.
What is the most important rule or teaching in the Christian religion?

To the Jews who had believed him, Jesus said, "If you hold to my teaching, you are really my disciples. Then you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free." John 8:31-32
On the last and greatest day of the Feast, Jesus stood and said in a loud voice, "If anyone is thirsty, let him come to me and drink. Whoever believes in me, as the Scripture has said, streams of living water will flow from within him." John 7:37-38
Christianity teaches freedom in Christ and truth through Jesus alone. If you are thirsty Jesus fills the thirst. The greatest of all commandments is to love God and love one another. (Matthew 22:36)

Being a Christian is not about rules or restrictions. People in the world will tell you that Christianity is only about doing things to try and please God and following strict rules. Well Jesus tells us differently.
How should we worship as Christians?

"Yet a time is coming and has now come when the true worshipers will worship the Father in spirit and truth, for they are the kind of worshipers the Father seeks. God is spirit, and his worshipers must worship in spirit and in truth." John 4:23-24

Jesus was speaking to the Samaritan woman who was inquiring about the proper place to worship –on the mountain or in the city of Jerusalem, but Jesus answered a time is coming when worship is in the heart of those that know me and my Father. She went on to respond, "I know the Messiah is coming. When he comes, he will explain everything to us".

This Bible story is classic. Here is Jesus in the flesh sharing the truth. The Messiah is right before her eyes and she cannot recognize Him. As Christians we no longer have to go before the altars in the city or the mountain before God. He is in our hearts and by the power of the Holy Spirit we can worship wherever and whenever we want. The Spirit is in us and God is a Spirit. We should be reverent and in awe for he is a consuming fire. (Hebrews 11:28-29)
Sickness
How can I be healed?

"When she heard about Jesus, she came up behind him in the crowd and touched his cloak, because she thought, if I just touch his clothes, I will be healed. Immediately her bleeding stopped and she felt in her body that she was freed from her suffering." Mark 5:27-29

This is the account of a woman who had a blood disease for twelve years. She had faith knowing that just one touch from Jesus would heal her. The verse continues as Jesus feels power go from Him instantly. He asks "who touched my clothes" and said to her "daughter your faith has healed you".

Have faith to believe that Jesus can heal you and if it is His will you will be healed. Go to Him in prayer believing that healing is available to you through Christ. Read the Bible accounts of the healings performed by Jesus and later by the disciples and the Apostle Paul as they walked in the authority given to them in Jesus. Pray without ceasing and never give up believing for healing. This woman never gave up believing for healing even after twelve years of sickness.
Is my sickness punishment from God?
"Therefore, there is now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus, because through Christ Jesus the law of the Spirit of life set me free from the law of sin and death." Romans 8:1-2
For believers in Jesus, all our sin – past, present and future – has already been punished on the cross. As Christians, we will never be punished for sin. That was done once for all.
Because of the sacrifice of Christ, God sees only the righteousness of Christ when He looks at us. Our sin has been nailed to the cross with Jesus, and we will never be punished for it.
Why won't God heal me?

"Trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own understanding; in all your ways acknowledge him and he will make your paths straight." Proverbs 3:5-6
"And we know in all things God works for the good of those who love him, who have been called according to his purpose." Romans 8:28

Struggling with illness is a huge burden. When you feel like God has ignored your prayers, abandoned you and allowed your pain to continue (which are very normal responses) you are leaning to your own understanding. It is an issue of faith. Do you love God and have you received the call to go according to His purpose and not your own? If you have, the Bible says He will work it out for good and He will make your paths straight. Some of the best things in life come out of our response to periods of pain, both physical and emotional. Look to the book of Job and read his faithful response to suffering. In the end, God gave Job three times more than what he had before the suffering.

(See question #2 on this topic) God did not cause your suffering and you are not being punished. Could God heal you? Sure, He is God, and the Bible says healing is possible through Christ (by his stripes we are healed). But it also says it is His will and not our own that matters. He knows everything and that includes His plans for you. We must trust Him to do what is best and to know what is best. When we consider the Bible's teaching on prayer, we learn that God may exercise His power in response to our prayer, or He may surprise us with a different course of action. In His wisdom He always does what is best.
How can I comfort someone when they are suffering?

"Therefore, whoever humbles himself like this child is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven." Matthew 18:4
"Dear children, let us not love with words or tongue but with actions and in truth." 1 John 3:18

A child cannot care for themselves so they are vulnerable. Jesus uses this analogy for us to help those unable to help themselves – children, the sick, the poor, the widows – and you should comfort with love by actually doing something allowing your actions to speak louder than your words.

It is easy to say I will pray for you and easy to tell someone you are available to help if they need you, but too often our words are meaningless because we forget to pray and our open offer to help is just that, an offer, but not a deed. When people are suffering they are usually embarrassed and feel uncomfortable giving up control to seek help. Let them see Christ in you. Show up at the hospital and keep them company. Take a meal over to their home. Really remember to pray. Your actions will speak louder than words and Christ will be seen in your deeds.
Can anything good come from my sickness?

"Consider it pure joy, my brothers, whenever you face trials of many kinds, because you know that the testing of your faith develops perseverance. Perseverance must finish its work so that you may be mature and complete, not lacking anything." James 1:2-4

Have pure joy in sickness? It is a tough word to receive, but your patience in the sickness will yield a mature and complete new you in Christ. We know according to Romans 8 "that all things work for good to those who love God and are called according to his purpose". Your testing will give you fruit! (See Galatians 5; Fruits of the Spirit; Long Suffering is a fruit)

Did you know for gold to be pure and radiant it has to go through the fire? If you are in the fire, you are one step closer to a new, beautiful, precious you! Patience is difficult, but it is necessary. Remember what your mom said, "all good things come to those who wait". Be still and know the Lord has a glorious plan for His child.
Sin
What is sin?

"If we claim to be without sin, we deceive ourselves and the truth is not in us. If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just and will forgive our sins and purify us from all unrighteousness." 1 John 1:8-9
"Everyone who sins breaks the law; in fact, sin is lawlessness." 1 John 3:4

Sin is lawlessness and wrong doing that separates us from God. Do not be deceived everyone has sin; the only perfect man was Jesus. If we confess our sins he is faithful to forgive us. See Keep It Real for our guide to sin as God defined it in the Bible.

Ten Commandments (Exodus 20:1-17) 1.You shall have no other gods before me 2.You shall have no idols 3.You shall not misuse the name of the Lord your God 4.Remember the Sabbath and keep it holy 5.Honor your father and mother 6.You shall not murder 7.You shall not commit adultery 8.You shall not steal 9.You shall not lie 10.You shall not covet
Did God create us to sin?
"Father forgive them for they know not what they do." Matthew 23:34

Jesus said this from the cross as He paid for our sins by dying for us. This verse shows His love for us and supports the claim that we were not created to sin, but have been deceived by Satan; blinded from the truth, not knowing what we are doing is sinful. However, born again believers in Christ, know the truth!

Man has to a large extent with Satan's influence turned the mind into a tool for self-deception. It happened first in the Garden of Eden (see Creation on this app) when the serpent tempted Adam and Eve. God created us in his own image, an image free from sin; yet, mankind began to hear only Satan's side of the story believing the lie of the enemy. The only way to die to sin is to give your life to the Lord. Pray daily asking Him to keep you from temptation and asking with a sincere heart for Him to forgive your sins. The Apostle Paul said "we must die daily" meaning to deny the nature of the sinful flesh and be born each new day with Christ.
How did sin come into the world?

"Therefore, just as sin entered the world through one man, and death through sin, and in this way death came to all men, because all sinned----for before the law was given, sin was in the world. But sin is not taken into account when there is no law." Romans 5:12-13
Sin entered the world through one man, meaning Adam, before God gave the law or commandments to Moses. And death through Adam is life through Christ.

Read Genesis Chapter 3 to discover the entry of sin into this world as the serpent, Satan, tempted Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden. Things were blissful and one bite of a forbidden apple from the forbidden tree of knowledge took all mankind to a destination of death and hell. We have a super hero Jesus who supernaturally swooped in, saved our souls, and destined our lives toward a promise of eternity. Do you know Him? Would you like to? He is your only hope from sin.
Will my sins keep me from Heaven?

"Like the rest, we were by nature objects of wrath. But because of his great love for us, God, who is rich in mercy, made us alive with Christ even when we were dead in transgressions---it is by grace you have been saved. And God raised us up with Christ and seated us with him in heavenly realms in Christ Jesus…" Ephesians 2:3-6

If you are alive in Christ, meaning Jesus is your savior, your sin or transgressions cannot keep you from Heaven. When you are born again in Christ your conviction to keep from sin becomes stronger and you desire to lead a less sinful life, but not a sinless life, for no one is without sin but Jesus. It is by His grace you are saved and if you know Him you will one day be in Heaven with Him. But if you do not know Christ, then yes, your sin can keep you from Heaven.

Jesus said that no one can snatch a Christian from His hands, regardless if they committed even the most grievous sin, such as murder. Legalists who misinterpret the Bible and scare Christians with their false manipulative teachings think that sin can cause a Christian to lose his or her salvation. This is absolutely not true. There is nothing we can do to earn salvation and there is nothing we can do to keep it. Salvation is a total gift from God that we cannot earn and that we do not deserve. If we truly believe from our hearts that we are all sinners and we cannot save ourselves, that Jesus Christ paid the full penalty for our sins and obtained eternal life for us through His death on the cross and resurrection, then we are saved.
Is one sin greater than another sin?

"I tell you the truth, all the sins and blasphemies of men will be forgiven them. But whoever blasphemes against the Holy Spirit will never be forgiven; he is guilty of an eternal sin. "He said this because they were saying." He has an evil spirit." Mark 3:28-30

These words were spoken by Jesus and he said all sin is forgiven, except when it comes to the Holy Spirit. The Trinity represents the Father, Son and Holy Spirit which is the God head. Jesus, the embodiment of the Trinity, is the Holy Spirit. When Jesus said only one sin is unforgivable it was said in response to a crowd that claimed he must be possessed by demons from Satan to be able to cast out demons. When they said he had an evil spirit, they were denouncing Jesus Himself. Simply unforgivable!

Sin is sin! There is no difference between telling a lie, having a jealous heart, dishonoring your parents or stealing. Even the most evil criminals in prison can be forgiven if they truly repent of their sins. All sin is equal in the eyes of the Lord and all forgiven if YOU KNOW JESUS; however, if you DO NOT KNOW JESUS that is the greatest sin never to be forgiven.
Witnessing
What does it mean to witness to others?

" "How then, can they call on the one they have not believed in? And how can they believe in the one of whom they have not heard and how can they hear without someone preaching to them? And how can they preach unless they are sent?" As it is written, "How beautiful are the feet of those who bring good news." " Romans 10:14-15

Witnessing to others is sharing the good news or the gospel of Jesus Christ. As Christians we are to be "fisher of men" (Matthew 4:19), to catch those lost. Those individuals witnessing or sharing their testimonies of what Jesus has done in their life will receive a special crown in Heaven known as The Crown of Rejoicing (1 Thess. 2:19).

When you think about how precious life is and how no one is promised tomorrow, the reality of death is palpable. As a Christian, you have confidence that your eternity is in Heaven, but others around you that do not know Christ are destined to an eternity in hell. Please cast your net deeper to catch all those lost before it is too late. If they haven't heard the gospel, maybe God placed you in their life to share the good news. Use this app to share Biblical truth with the lost. Be fisher of men just like Jesus wants you to be!
How do I witness to others?

"Be wise in the way you act toward outsiders; make the most of every opportunity. Let your conversation be always full of grace, seasoned with salt, so that you may know how to answer everyone." Colossians 4:5

When you witness it should be in kindness and graciousness with words that are not offensive, but loving. Do not become argumentative or accusatory. You are the mouth piece from God sent for that moment to share the gospel, so act accordingly. You should conduct yourself just like you would if Jesus was standing right next to you. (See Keep It Real for practical guidelines)

Make sure to pray before you witness. Keep it simple, share your salvation story or testimony, and memorize a verse when possible to share, ask questions, listen with patience and be a positive example/witness for Christ. If you see a change taking place and a genuine interest to know Christ better is developing, encourage them to attend church with you or pray with them. If you feel comfortable you can pray the sinner's prayer with them should they accept Christ in your conversation.
Pray: Dear Lord, greater is He that is in me than he that is in the world. I am equipped by Christ and His authority to speak in truth, wisdom, love and spirit. Let my words be seasoned with salt. Let my words be directly from your mouth to mine. Give me courage to stand up on your behalf as you did on mine. Please allow this child of God to open their heart to know you as I do. In Jesus' Name, AMEN
Who should I start witnessing to?

Then he said to Thomas, "Put your finger here; see my hands. Reach out your hand and put it into my side. Stop doubting Thomas and believe." John 20:27
Then Jesus told him, "Because you have seen me, you have believed; blessed are those who have not seen and yet have believed." John 20:27

Thomas was one of the disciples. He was in Jesus' close circle; yet, he did not believe Jesus had visited the disciples after His death. Jesus had to prove to Thomas that He was alive. The point is this, even if you hang out with Godly people and think they truly believe, it is possible they really do not know Jesus as the resurrected King. The best place to start witnessing is in your circle of friends and family.

Start witnessing to your friends and acquaintances. People you feel comfortable around, but people you aren't sure if they know Christ personally. Hopefully they have seen Christ in you and it won't be shocking for them to talk with you about God. Work God into the conversation and feel out the waters. Try to find out if they are a believer or not. If not, use witnessing tools from church, websites or this application and begin to share your personal story of why you know God is real. If you don't have a specific story to share, talk about the existence of conscience, guilt, the search for purpose and religions in general. Let the Bible support your words. (See Question #2 on this application for more information)
Will witnessing to others matter to God?

"I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race. I have kept the faith. Now there is in store for me the crown of righteousness, which the Lord, the righteous Judge, will award to me on that day – and not only to me, but also to all who have longed for his appearing," 2 Timothy 4:7-8

The Apostle Paul committed most of his life to witnessing. He traveled all over the countries along the Mediterranean Sea. He started the first churches founded in Christ and spread the word of God with passion and vigor. He compares his journey to a race and a fight to the finish. Paul knew the Lord would crown him in righteousness and others along the way because the Lord told him he would. Yes, our witnessing matters to God!

Have you ever competed in a race for a school track team? Your performance can help the team place. To be prepared to run the race, it is important you wear the right running shoes, get positioned properly at the starting blocks to get off to a good start, stay in your lane and pace yourself along the way pushing to the goal. Running for Jesus is a lot like a race too. He shrouds our feet fitted with the readiness of the gospel of peace to get us going, gives us position of great worth in Him, He keeps us on track with the Holy Spirit and in worship/prayer/faith we have endurance to claim the prize. Paul was right. We are in the race of our lives and when we win others to Christ the whole team wins too!
What does the Bible say about witnessing?

"Through him and for his name's sake, we received grace and apostleship to call people from among all the Gentiles to the obedience that comes from faith. And you also are among those who are called to belong to Jesus Christ." Romans 1:5-6

This is just one of many verses that commission us as called people to spread the word of Christ. We are apostles (religious messengers or ambassadors) in Christ. We have a title as believers, making us crucial members in the Kingdom of God. You are a name sake of Christ.

A witness gives firsthand account of something seen, heard or experienced. A witness serves as a sign or evidence. A witness has personal knowledge to share, can attest to the authenticity of something or someone. Finally, a witness affirms their religious faith. You are an apostle, ambassador and witness, all magnificent titles you possess as a Christian.
Bible
How do I know the Bible is true?

"For the word of God is living and active, sharper than any double-edged sword, it penetrates even to dividing soul and spirit, joints, and marrow; it judges the thoughts and attitudes of the heart." Hebrews 4:12

The Bible is so unique that merely reading it brings power. When we consider that the Scriptures were written over many years, by different people in various parts of the world, without any contradiction, we can only conclude that the Bible is the Truth of God.

The Bible is the written record of God's revelation to humankind. It is one book, and yet is a compilation of 66 books written over a period of almost 2000 years! The diversity of its contributors ranges from a king to a shepherd, from a doctor to a choirmaster, from a former tax collector to a former fisherman. Yet this diversity contributes to a central unity of purpose: the reconciliation of man to his Creator and God.
(Printed with permission of the American Tract Society)
What do the Scriptures Say About Themselves?
"For prophecy never had its origin in the will of man, but men spoke from God as they were carried along by the Holy Spirit." 2 Peter 1:21
The Bible was written by men, but it was the Spirit of God who guided them and made sure it was accurate and correct.

Why should we trust the Bible? Some skeptics say that there are many ways to live a good life and that we don't have to bother following the Bible. They say that as long as we do our best, God will accept us. If that is true, How do you define what's good and right? Who has the correct standards? How can something be right for one person and not for another? Who determines the consequences for doing wrong?
(Printed with permission of the American Tract Society)
What does Jesus say about the people and events of the Bible?

"Do not think that I have come to abolish the law or the Prophets; I have not come to abolish them but to fulfill them. I tell you the truth, until heaven and earth disappear, not the smallest letter, not the least stroke of a pen, will by any means disappear from the Law until everything is accomplished." Matthew 5:17-18

Whenever Jesus quoted the Bible, He used it as an absolute authority, indicating its reliability and truth. The law was his reference to Scripture and the prophets were the people God used to write the law as he gave it to them through His Spirit.

Jesus spoke of many people that were faithful to write God's law and abide by it, such as Moses and David. Jesus even went to the temple in Nazareth and read from the scroll of Isaiah saying, "Today this scripture is fulfilled in your hearing." (Luke 4:21) Jesus was the walking mouthpiece of righteousness, the word of God in the flesh, promoting, fulfilling and living the Bible in action, deed and word.
(Printed with permission of the American Tract Society)
How can I understand the Bible?

"Do not merely listen to the word, and so deceive yourselves. Do what it says…The man who looks intently into the perfect law that gives freedom, and continues to do this…he will be blessed in what he does." James 1:22-25

If you really want to know what the Bible has to say, you need to study it! God promises to honor our efforts. Bibles are written in different versions or "translations". The Old Testament was originally written in Hebrew and the New Testament in Greek. Each translation has its own strengths and weaknesses. The King James Version (KJV) is excellent, but you must use a dictionary as you read because it uses language typical of the time it was translated (1611). The New American Standard Version (NASV) is believed by many to be one of the most accurate translations and is an excellent study Bible. The American Standard Version (ASV) is also excellent. The New King James Version (NKJV) is high on the recommended list. The New International Version (NIV) tries to make the text as easy to understand as possible and is an excellent reading Bible, but not a good study Bible. Although the exact choice of words or sentence structure is different in each translation, the meaning is identical. Take the words of Jesus in Mark 16:16 from three "versions" as an example; NIV: "Whoever believes and is baptized will be saved". KJV: "He that believeth and is baptized shall be saved". NAS: "He who has believed and has been baptized shall be saved" Different words and sentences but the meaning is identical. See “Keep It Real” for guidelines to help you get more from your study time.

1.Ask God for help. "Open my eyes that I may see wonderful things in your law" Psalm 119:18. His Holy Spirit will help us as He teaches us the truth of His Word (John 14:26). 2.Look for the meaning of the words you are reading. When you come across words you don't understand, use a dictionary to find their meanings. 3.Consider the context. Don't just read one verse. Try to read a few verses before and after so you understand what that section is talking about. 4.You won't get it all on the first day. It takes time to understand the Bible. When God created the world in six days are they 24 hour days?

"Thus the heavens and the earth were completed in all their vast array. By the seventh day God had finished the work he had been doing; so on the seventh day he rested from all his work." Genesis 2:1-2

In order to answer this question we must look at the Hebrew word for "day" and the context in which it appears in Genesis. The Hebrew word "Yom" means a literal 24 hour period of time. In these verses it is used in conjunction with ordinal numbers (i.e. the seventh day). Yom plus a number indicates an ordinary 24 hour day.

Yes, God meant 24 hour days when He created the world in six days. According to Exodus 20:9-11, God used six literal days to create the world in order to serve as a model for man's workweek: work six days, rest one. Certainly God could have created everything in an instant if He wanted to. But apparently He had us in mind even before He made us (on the sixth day) and wanted to provide an example for us to follow.

Seth was born to Adam and Eve after their first son Cain killed his brother Abel and was banished from the Lord's presence, then the genealogy as listed in Genesis chapters 5 and 11 provide the age at which Adam and his descendants each fathered the next generation in an ancestral time line from Adam to Abraham. By determining where Abraham fits into history chronologically and adding up the ages provided in Genesis 5 and 11, it becomes apparent that the Bible teaches the earth to be about 6000 years old, give or take a few hundred years.

Given the fact that, according to the Bible, Adam was created on the sixth day of our planet's existence, we can determine a biblically-based, approximate age for the earth by looking at the chronological details of the human race. This assumes that the Genesis account is accurate, that the six days of creation were literal 24-hour periods, and that there were no gaps in the chronology of Genesis. Our beliefs about the age of the earth rest on our faith of the scriptures.
