The only way is through me he said.

You can't get to Heaven by just being good or doing good things such as serving as a volunteer. Those are all great things and worthy of reward once you GET to Heaven. But, to get to Heaven, you must know Jesus as your Lord and Savior, and recognize that you are a sinner. And as a sinner you need his grace to save you. Do you know him? If you don't, would you like to? Welcome him in your life today.
For more information go to the "Saved" questions and pray the sinner's prayer for salvation today.
Is Heaven real?
"After the Lord Jesus had spoken to them, he was taken up into Heaven and he sat at the right hand of God" Mark 16:19

Yes, there is a heaven. Jesus not only went before us, he went FOR us. He is alive and serving as King with God. Heaven is not the white clouds and harp that you see on TV or on the internet. Heaven is where God lives with his son. Life in Heaven is all about God. It is forever and unshakeable.

What's real in your life? The love of friends and family? You can't see it, but you know it's there. Heaven is the same. It exists. God, your heavenly father loves you, just as your friends and family do.
Pray to Jesus to feel his love, it is REAL!
Where is Heaven?

"As the time approached for him to be taken up to heaven, Jesus resolutely set out for Jerusalem." Luke 9:51
"Taking the five loaves and the two fish and looking up to heaven, he gave thanks and broke the loaves." Mark 6:41

Jesus referred to Heaven as being "up" in direction. We do not know whether it is a place "in the heavens" (the universe beyond the Earth) or outside space and time as we know it. We do know Heaven is some place based on the word of God through scriptures such as these. In addition, people have shared their experiences as they were dying and visualized Heaven. They returned to tell their stories, but that place described wasn't Earth.

To understand the exact location is not for us to know until God reveals it to us. Our goal should be to strive to get there when our time on earth has come to an end. Until then, it is beyond our imagination!
To read more about Heaven the actual place, check out these Bible verses: John 1:32, 6:33, 6:42, 18:36; Matthew 28:2; Acts 1:2; Revelation 10:1.
What is Heaven like?
"In my Father's house are many rooms; if it were not so, I would have told you. I am going there to prepare a place for you." John 14:2

Jesus spoke of Heaven often and in this verse he describes it as a vast place for all that follow him. Heaven has been described as a beautiful city of pure gold where you will rest and fellowship in love and joy. It is a place of worship and a great reward. Heaven is all these things and more!

You've heard the phrase, "It was like Heaven" or the song, "Almost Heaven". These comparisons use Heaven as a term to describe wonderful things or experiences. Heaven is simply Heaven! It is beautiful, marvelous, phenomenal, amazing…get the picture?
To read more about what Heaven is like, check out these Bible verses: Matthew 5:11; John 14:3; Hebrews 11:16; Revelation 15:4, 20:2, 21:4, 21:18-21.
Will I know anyone in Heaven?

"The time came when the beggar died and the angels carried him to Abraham's side. The rich man also died and was buried. In hell, where he was in torment, he looked up and saw Abraham far away with Lazarus by his side." Luke 16:22-23

In this historical account of the afterlife of a rich man and Lazurus, a beggar, Jesus used their proper names to show it was not just an example or parable. The rich man recognized the beggar that once lay outside his gate on Earth. The verse goes on to describe the scene. Now in hell, the man is seeing Lazarus in Heaven, as he looks up, begs him to give him drink for his burning lips and begs him to warn his five brothers to avoid the torment he has come to know in hell. Even in hell, we do not necessarily lose our memories of our families on Earth or acquaintances.

Yes, if your loved one has died and knew Jesus Christ as his or her personal Savior here on Earth, you will see them in Heaven! Make sure you share this scripture with your loved ones, so they can avoid the eternal torment that the rich man suffers.
Hell
Is there really a hell?

"I am the Living One; I was dead, and behold I am alive for ever and ever! And I hold the keys of death and Hades." Revelation 1:18
"The lake of fire is the second death. If anyone’s name is not found in the Book of Life, he was thrown into the lake of fire." Revelation 20:14-15

Hell is referred to as Hades and also Abaddon in the Bible. It is also known as the lake of fire. It is a real place. In contrast to the gods of paganism, Christ possesses life in the essential nature (He is alive) and He has total dominion (control) over death and hell.

At the end of time we will all stand before judgment and the people whose names are in the Book of Life (those believers in Christ Jesus) will be in heaven forever and ever and those people whose names are not in the Book of Life will be cast into hell. If we believe what the living God says, then we do know that hell is a very real place. As a born again Christian, His simple plan of salvation given to us with the spilling of His blood will allow us to live forever with Christ and our loved ones in heaven. The Lion of Judah, The Bright and Morning Star will hold and keep your soul and your immortal body intact and you will live for eternity! Amen.
Where is hell?

"When he ascended on high, he led captives in his train and gave gifts to men. What does he ascended mean except that he also descended to the lower earthly regions. He who descended is the very on who ascended higher than all the heavens, in order to fill the whole universe." Ephesians 7:10

The Bible states that after his death, Jesus descended into Hell. But his soul did not remain there, nor did his body decay, he ascended with captives on the tail of His rope to Heaven. The implication is that Hell is located underground, apparently in a cavern deep under the surface of the earth. Also, consider the scripture in the Heaven topic: Luke 16:22-23, where Lazarus looked up from hell and saw Abraham.
Hell is a place below and beneath the earth. Symbolically it is literally the lowest of low, beneath you and me. As Christians we are above it and ascending even higher in Christ one day.
What is hell like?

"But the cowardly, the unbelieving, the vile, the murderers, the sexually immoral, those who practice magic arts, the idolaters and all liars – their place will be in the fiery lake of burning sulfur." Revelation 21:8

Hell will be hot, in the Scriptures; one of the most common attributes mentioned about Hell is its high temperature. In order for sulfur to form a lake, it must be molten. Thus, its temperature must be at or below 444.6° C or 832° F. That is the boiling point of sulfur. Those that do not know Christ will not escape the fire.

Hell is a place of torment and bondage. According to Matthew 8:12, it is also dark and according to Mark 9:44, there will be flesh eating worms. It is such a horrible place that it has been made a curse word. In anger it is spewed from mouths to condemn others knowing that telling someone "to go to hell" is the worst possible destination. The only way to avoid going is to know Jesus as your Lord and Savior. (See Saved Topic)
Does Satan live in hell?

"And the Lord said to Satan "Where have you come from?" Satan answered the Lord, "From roaming through the earth and going back and forth in it." " Job 2:2 "Be self-controlled and alert. Your enemy the devil prowls around like a roaring lion looking for someone to devour." 1 Peter 5:8

References describing the abode of Satan are few but adequate to reveal the truth. In Job 1:7, Satan tells the Lord again that he is roaming the earth just like he told the Lord in Job 2:2, we find Satan coming to appear before God, and the LORD asks Satan a very pointed question. Satan's answer in both instances is that he is roaming about the earth. Also in 1 Peter he is prowling, so according to the Bible, Satan is nomadic and not in one place. Although he is on the earth, he is not the master "the earth is the Lord's, and the fullness of the world, and they that dwell in it" (Psalm 24:1).

It seems reasonable to us that Satan is in hell, but Scripture tells us otherwise. Yes, when Christ comes to conquer Satan he will throw him into the Lake of Fire for 1000 years, but right now he is walking about trying to accomplish his goal to defeat God's kingdom which is us. He will not succeed for the Bible tells us so! Resist the enemy and flee from him when he tries to come to visit. (See Ephesians 2:2 for more Scriptures about where Satan travels)
How can I avoid hell?

"No, in all these things we are more than conquerors through him who loved us. For I am convinced that neither death, nor life, neither angels nor demons, neither the present nor the future, nor any powers, neither height nor depth, nor anything else in all creation, will be able to separate us from the love of God that is in Jesus Christ our Lord." Romans 8:37-39

This is a remarkable scripture. NOTHING can keep you from eternal life in Heaven as long as you ARE IN CHRIST JESUS. If you believe Jesus died for you that is your key to His kingdom in Heaven…he took the key from hell for you. (See Question 1 on Hell Topic)

Many people worry that their sin is so great that it cannot keep them from hell. Sincerely, if you know Jesus, your sin cannot keep you from Heaven. (See Sin, Saved, and Heaven Topics for more information on this subject)
Hope
When I have lost hope, what do I do?
"Why are you downcast, O my soul? Why so disturbed within me? Put your hope in God, for I will yet praise him, my Savior and my God." Psalm 42:11

David, the psalmist, posed this question and found his answer in God. For your hope is in the Almighty Savior and when you lose hope praise Him. Your praise will elevate Him in worship and elevate you at the same time.

If anyone had reason to lose hope it was David. His best friend's father was trying to kill him and he had to leave his family and home. He spent years fighting battles and felt the presence of his enemies all about him. These were just some of the many reasons he had to lose hope, but his hope was in God. He worshipped with the most heartfelt emotions making the Book of Psalms a pure and true open dialog between a once shepherd boy and his savior. God made him a powerful King and a mighty nation! Read the Psalms (Psalm 61 if crying out in hopelessness) and worship your Lord for He is your hope.
What is my hope as a Christian?
"----the faith and love that spring from the hope that is stored up for you in heaven and that you have already heard about in the word of truth, the gospel that has come to you." Colossians 1:5

Our hope is the combination of faith and love that we have as believers in Christ knowing that no matter what this world holds our promise given to us by the gospel according to God is eternal life in Heaven. (See Heaven topic and read how lovely it will be)

Colossians 1:5 says our hope is stored in Heaven. What images come to mind when you think about hope being stored? Is it an image of a hope chest, full of beautiful memories and things? Think about that concept in general. If you could take every moment of optimism, expectation, anticipation, wishful thinking, or idealistic dream and place it in a sacred location comprised of precious gold and jewels where choirs of angels saturate the atmosphere with music as you bask in the glory of God with all your senses heightened to smell, taste, see, hear, and touch the utter splendor of hope itself…Jesus! Wow! What a hope chest that would be! Guess what? Hope in Jesus is the real deal!
What happens when I put my hope in people/things and not in God?

"----remember that at that time you were separate from Christ, excluded from citizenship in Israel and foreigners to the covenants of the promise, without hope and without God in the word. But now in Christ Jesus you who once were far away have been brought near through the blood of Christ." Ephesians 2:12-13

Paul was speaking to the church in Ephesus about the hopelessness they faced believing somehow they could save themselves. They were lost separated from Christ, but now in Jesus, they can place their trust knowing hope is possible and claim citizenship in Him. Peace comes as a citizen of Christ. A promise of hope by the ultimate promise keeper—Jesus.

How often do we place our hopes in people thinking they can save us? If I could just get that recommendation from so and so, I know the job will be mine. If I screw up, my mom will take care of it for me. If my church leader lets me go on this mission trip, my good deeds will make up for all my sin. When we place our hope in people and the ways of the world we will always be disappointed. Did you pray asking God first, before putting your hope in the circumstances? Ultimately, you are saying, "God you don't matter as much as______". I challenge you to place your hopes in God for whatever you are looking people to fill. Let Him fill you with overflowing living water that quenches every thirst and every hope.
Jesus, I place my hope in you and you alone. You are not like a man that lies. You keep your promises. And your promise means you will not disappoint or abandon me. Thank you Lord, Amen.
What is the difference between faith and hope?

"For in this hope we were saved. But hope that is seen is no hope at all. Who hopes for what he already has? But if we hope for what we do not yet have, we wait for it patiently." Romans 8:24-25
"Now faith is being sure of what we hope for and certain of what we do not see." Hebrews 11:1

Hope is a confident expectation regarding things unclear or unknown. Faith is being sure of what we hope for and certain of what we do not see. So hope is the expectation and faith is the assurance the expectation will be fulfilled.

Here is an example of faith and hope coming together. I hope (confident expectation) that this application will glorify the Lord and I stand in faith (patient assurance) that many will come to know Jesus more intimately with i Dial Jesus.
What is the difference between the Old and New Testaments as it pertains to hope?

"Therefore, since we have such a hope we are very bold. We are not like Moses, who put a veil over his face to keep the Israelites from gazing at it while the radiance was fading away. But their minds were made dull, for to this day the same veil remains when the old covenant is read. It has been removed, because only in Christ is it taken away." 2 Corinthians 3:12-14

Christ is the difference. The old covenant separated us from the glory of God. A veil had to come between us and God. The new covenant (when Christ died for our sins and became the lamb shedding his blood for us) gave hope to the sinner. The veil in the temple was torn literally from top to bottom, no longer separating us from the glory of God. Christ's death gave us access to go directly to Him.

Christ gave you full access to hope. It didn't use to be that way. Priests would have to bring an animal to the altar and offer it as a blood sacrifice to God. They were the only ones allowed access behind the curtain to enter the holy of holies before the Lord. The veil was torn and the sacrifice was made on your behalf. Go directly to the King of Kings. It was His gift to you. Claim your authority in Christ to be bold in hope.
Jealousy
What does God say about jealousy?

"You shall not covet your neighbor's wife. You shall not set your desire on your neighbor's house or land, his manservant or maid servant, his ox or donkey, or anything that belongs to your neighbor." Deuteronomy 5:21

This is the 10th commandment given by the Lord to Moses. God commands us to stay away from jealousy. It is a sin. Today we don't relate to the term ox or manservant, but we can relate to cars and maids. God tells us not to covet or be jealous for other people's things.

Many have become content to "want" for things as if they were "needs" which are not same. We are surrounded by advertisements, celebrity magazines and movies that feed us full of desires to want material things and relationships with people that are rooted out of a jealous nature. "A heart at peace gives life to the body, but envy rots the bones." (Proverbs: 14:30) God says envy/jealousy makes us rotten. Try to be content with what you have and pray that the Lord will help you fight the desires to want what everyone else has.
Spend time serving the poor. In blessing them, you will be blessed, and soon your wants will seem less important.
Why am I jealous of other people?
"Or do you think Scripture says without reason that the spirit he caused to live in us envies intensely? But he gives us more grace…" James 4:5-6

In us lives a free will to be jealous and envious. God knows this and scripture addresses it because it is a big issue to face as a Christian, but God gives us grace and forgives us. Later in verse 6, HE asks us to submit to HIM and resist the devil, and he will flee from you.

We are human and "of the flesh" as the Bible would say. We are sinners and we want the BMW Jessica drives, or the popularity Nick has, or the slim body Jordan has…the list goes on and on. And Jesus' grace goes on and on. His grace is without end. Submit yourselves before HIM asking with a sincere heart to rise above jealousy.
How can I control my jealous nature?

"Whoever has my commands and obeys them, he is the one who loves me. He who loves me will be loved by my Father and I too will love him and show myself to him." John 14:21
"Be still before the Lord….do not fret when men succeed in their ways, when they carry out their wicked schemes." Proverbs 37:7

"Do not covet" (or be jealous) is the 10th commandment and Jesus tells us to keep his commandments. Also, we are to wait for the Lord for our needs and not to worry for successes or potentially jealous things we want that make us have a jealous spirit.

Controlling our nature to die to sin is the most difficult part of living a Christian life. If our desire is to please the Lord, then we desire to keep his commandments and obey them. HE will show us HIS love and HE will fill those empty places that make us long for the wrong things. We have to recognize that jealousy brings out wickedness. Pray: Jesus, I can't control my jealous heart, but you can. Your word says you are jealous for me to find you and love you. Make my desires your desires. AMEN.
Does my jealousy affect other people?

"Let us not become conceited, provoking and envying each other." James 5:26
"For where you have envy and selfish ambition there you find disorder and every evil practice." James 3:16
Yes, jealousy provokes others. It causes chaos in people. Also, it makes evil reside in its presence.

Have you ever had a boyfriend or girlfriend that was easily upset when you spent time with other people? Maybe you struggle with jealousy when your friends spend time outside your company. Why is that? It could be insecurity or fear. Inevitably, in those situations, someone ends up upset over words said and things done by the jealous party as they try to control or manipulate the other person. Healthy relationships cannot exist in the presence of evil and jealousy is evil. After all, it does answer to the name "green-eyed monster". Open the door to your heart, give it to God and say good-bye before it tries to bring you down and everyone else in your path.
Do you know who is jealous for you?

"Do not worship any other gods, for the Lord, whose name is Jealous, is a jealous God." Exodus 34:14
"For I am jealous for you with a godly jealousy, I promised you to one husband, to Christ, so that I might present you as a pure virgin before him. But I am afraid that just as Eve was deceived by the serpent's cunning, your mind may somehow be led astray from your sincere and pure devotion to Christ." 2 Corinthians 11:3

God is jealous for you. He wants your worship and devotion. God wants you to want HIM as much as HE wants you. In the scripture from Paul, he speaks of Christ as the bridegroom and you are the bride. He desires you come to HIM with your whole heart, body and soul.

We can easily be led astray by distractions of life. A Godly jealousy is the best possible kind of jealous. God's jealousy is IN LOVE. Right now, tell the Lord how you love HIM and appreciate HIS unfailing love for you even when you don't deserve it. Ask HIM to show you how to love HIM more.
Leadership
What does it mean to be a Christian Leader?
"I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep." John 10:11

Jesus Christ refers to himself as the Shepherd. The Shepherd has responsibility for his sheep. This includes such things as feeding them, comforting them, protecting them, and leading them. Jesus leads his "flock" (children) by modeling godliness and righteousness in his own life and encouraging others to follow his example. Christian leaders serve with compassion, patience, encouragement, and discipline.

Pray that God will teach you how to model leadership through the example He gave us in His Son Jesus Christ. Leadership is a position of humble, loving service. Can you choose to serve others before serving yourself? How does it make you feel when you apply this philosophy? Remember what your grandmother always said at Christmas, "it is better to give than to receive". This is the foundation of Christian Leadership.
What makes someone a Christian Leader?
"Not that we are competent in ourselves to claim anything for ourselves; but our competence comes form God." 2 Corinthians 3:5

Leadership is not given through a title, but when someone is already doing the work of a leader and has the character of a leader. Leadership is demonstrated before you are recognized as a leader. God has given each of us a gift, such as a beautiful voice, or the ability to write stories, or to calculate math problems in our head. Leadership is another of these gifts. God chooses his leaders. You did not choose me, but I chose you (John 15:16). This fact alone rules out leadership based on seniority, degrees earned, prestige in the community, or personal friendships.

Do you know what gift God has blessed you with? (See My Gifts Topic) Could it be Leadership? Think of situations that you have found yourself in with your friends or family. When difficult situations arise, are you an Upstander or a Bystander?
What is Servant Leadership?
"Let another praise you, and not your own mouth; someone else, and not your own lips." Proverbs 27:2

Servant leadership is one of the most popular leadership models around today. The concept was developed by Robert K. Greenleaf in 1970. The servant leader serves the person he/she leads which implies that employees, fellow students, are the focus rather than the ultimate end goal (said another way: people first). Servant leaders devote themselves to serving the needs of the student body, friends or youth organizations. They focus on meeting the needs of those they lead; they develop others to bring out the best in them; they coach/mentor others; they encourage self expression; they facilitate personal growth in all who work with them; and they listen and build a sense of community.

Do you lead by your conscience, your inward moral sense of what is right and what is wrong? Morality is really the overlapping between the law and behavior. When making decisions do you consider what is kind and what is unkind; what contributes and what detracts; what adds beauty and what destroys it; what is true and what is false? These are leadership skills that you can start to practice today! Go ahead, I dare you to set yourself apart. Servant leadership can start with your family.
Will my ego hurt me as a leader?
"For whoever exalts himself will be humbled and whoever humbles himself will be exalted." Matthew 23:12

Ego focuses on one's own survival, pleasure or winning at the detriment of others. Ego is selfish ambition, fulfilling ones own agenda. Ego is threatened by negative feedback, it make us look at the facts in a way that protects us (self-preservation). An ego left unchecked can be a disaster for you and your relationships.

In order to keep your ego in the background, you must rethink your leadership style. Rather than using power and authority over someone else, try using reasoning, persuasion, kindness, and empathy. The result of such a modeled leadership style will be one built on trust and openness.
My friends generally think of me as the leader. Do I have to be perfect?

"You are the light of the world. A city on a hilltop that cannot be hidden. Neither do people light a lamp and put it under a bowl. Instead they put it on a stand, and it gives light to everyone in the house. In the same way, let your light shine before men, that they may see your good deeds and praise your Father in heaven." Matthew 5:14-16

Good friends inspire us. They don't hide their imperfections, but display how they trust God in the midst of them. Those friends who appear faultless intimidate us. An effective leader needs to be real and this means acknowledging our weaknesses and mistakes. Leaders share their troubles and are able to be a good follower too.

No one is perfect, except our Savior Jesus Christ. If you will trust in the word of the Lord, through reading and understanding of the Gospel, you can aspire to be as much like Christ as possible. This does not come easily or at once. We must grow in our spiritual maturity. Just as we expect different behavior from a baby, a child, a teenager, and an adult, so God expects different behavior from us, depending our spiritual development. We are all sinners saved by grace.
Love
What does loving like God require of me?

"Teacher, which is the greatest commandment in the Law?' Jesus replied: 'Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your mind. This is the first and greatest commandment. And the second is like it: Love your neighbor as yourself." Matthew 22:36-39

As a followers of Jesus we are commanded to love, it's not a choice. If we call ourselves Christians, then we should strive to live our lives as a reflection of Jesus' love. This means putting God first in our lives, and allowing His love to overwhelm us and fill every part of who we are. Then that same love should spill out of us onto others, loving them as we would want or desire for ourselves.

As a follower of Jesus, loving others with Jesus' love should become a natural part of who we are. If His love is a part of our character, then it shouldn't take too much effort to love even the difficult people in our lives. It's not about trying to be someone you're not, but honestly making love a foundational part of who you are. In your encounters with people today, stop and ask God how you can demonstrate His love to them.
How do I love God if I Can't see Him or touch Him?
"Now faith is being sure of what we hope for and certain of what we do not see". Hebrews 11:1

If we were able to tangibly touch God or see Jesus in the flesh, then there would be no need for faith. God is bigger than we can comprehend, so it's silly to think that we could limit His greatness to our small lives and little understanding. Faith enables us to see God working in the lives of His people, and it is what gives us hope.

Love for God is different than the love you have for your family, or your boyfriend or girlfriend. It's a greater love than surpasses understanding, not a touchy-feely kind of love. We express our love for God through worship, prayer, spending quiet time with Him, serving Him, and loving others. Pray that God would reveal Himself to you, so that you can experience His powerful love in your life.
How can I have God's love in my life?
"And so we know and rely on the love God has for us. God is love. Whoever lives in love lives in God, and God in him." 1 John 4:16

The essence of who God is can be defined in one word: Love. Love is not just a characteristic of God, but He is the ultimate embodiment of love. It cannot be taken from God, which means that His love for us will never run out or disappear. We can always count on God, and when we love others, that is God living Himself out through us.

When we go throughout our day loving others, it is not just being a good person, but it is God working in our lives. In which areas of your life do you need to express more love? When you allow love to win, that is giving God total control, and God reigns! Tell God that you want to rely on Him and let love rule in your life.
Does God still love me if I sin?

"But God demonstrates his own love for us in this: While we were still sinners, Christ died for us." Romans 5:8
"For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life, through Christ Jesus our Lord". Romans 6:23
"For I am convinced that neither death nor life, neither angels nor demons, neither the present nor the future, nor any powers, neither height nor depth, nor anything else in all creation, will be able to separate us from the love of God that is in Christ Jesus our Lord." Romans 8:38-39

We all sin, but many times we sin even though our hearts know its wrong, or it "just happened". All sins are contrary to Christ's character and deserve punishment. However, God still lavishes His love and blessings on us. He wants us to ask forgiveness of our sins and He will give us grace.

Grace does not give us permission to purposefully sin, as it's not freedom to indulge in sin, but rather a way to experience His love and live in the freedom we have in a relationship with God. Nothing can separate us from the love of God! Take a moment to repent of sin in your life and thank God for His unconditional love.
Do I have to love everyone?
"You have heard that it was said, 'Love your neighbor and hate your enemy.' But I tell you: Love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you". Matthew 5: 43-44

Yes, we do have to love everyone. By doing so we are extending the grace and mercy that God gives us to those around us, regardless of the circumstance. God commands that his followers show grace and mercy to others and be representatives of His love even when those people seem unworthy of love or seem perhaps as enemies. We need to love everyone and leave the judgment up to God.

Allow love to define your life. Live your life for Christ and treat people with love and respect. You will be extending God's love to people, regardless of whether or not you think they deserve it. It's for all people, so show love in all situations, and let love and goodness win. For that is truly being Christ like. Pray that God's love would touch others through you, genuinely and powerfully.
My Gifts
What are spiritual gifts?

"Now to each one the manifestation of the Spirit is given for the common good. To one there is given through the Spirit the message of wisdom, to another the message of knowledge by means of the same Spirit, to another faith by the same Spirit, to another gifts of healing by that one Spirit, to another miraculous powers, to another prophecy, to another distinguishing between spirits, to another speaking in different kinds of tongues, and to still another the interpretation of tongues. All these are the work of one and the same Spirit, and he gives them to each one, just as he determines."1 Corinthians 12: 7-11
The Holy Spirit works in each one of us in different ways. God has uniquely created each of us with gifts and abilities that contribute powerfully to the Church.

Discovering your spiritual gift is exciting and often confirmation for why you are wired a certain way. Whether it's an overwhelming feeling of compassion, or a desire to work behind the scenes, or it is a natural desire to lead a movement of people, all these point toward your God-given gifts. Examine your strengths, talents, and abilities and consider how they are to be used for His purposes. Pray and ask the Lord to show you your gifts and He will give you insight.
Does God need me?

"…..all things were created by him and for him." Colossians 1:16
"…I urge you to live a life worthy of the calling you have received." Ephesians 4:1
"The God who made the world and everything in it is the Lord of heaven and earth and does not live in temples built by hands. And he is not served by human hands, as if he needed anything, because he himself gives all men life and breath and everything else." Acts 17:24-25

All things point back to our Creator. God created all things which are to be used for His purposes. He did not uniquely create us so that we could turn from Him to serve other masters. All of creation should point back to and reflect Him, and make the most of the gift of life that He has given us, reflecting and representing Him well.

God doesn't need you as the passage in Acts 17:25 says, but he wants you. He is a jealous God, wanting you for His purposes and not serving worldly things. He wants you to be a recipient of His love, as God IS love and love is shared. Jesus is the origin and purpose of all creation. He's created you and gifted you in such ways, so serving Him is to be your expression of love for Him. Consider how you could show God the fullest extent of your love by allowing Him to use you and mold you in new ways.
Are some gifts more important than others?

"The eye cannot say to the hand, "I don't need you!" And the head cannot say to the feet, "I don't need you!" On the contrary, those parts of the body that seem to be weaker are indispensable, and the parts that we think are less honorable we treat with special honor. And the parts that are unpresentable are treated with special modesty, while our presentable parts need no special treatment. But God has combined the members of the body and has given greater honor to the parts that lacked it, so that there should be no division in the body, but that its parts should have equal concern for each other. If one part suffers, every part suffers with it; if one part is honored, every part rejoices with it." 1 Corinthians 12: 21-26

God has uniquely designed each of us and he gave each of us our gifts with equal value. Although some have been appointed as leaders and some serve less glamorously or behind the scenes; all parts contribute to the whole. The Body is comprised of all God's people and all are equally important despite our differences.

As 1 Corinthians mentions, we all serve as different parts to the whole body. Imagine if we were all hands, or all feet? It wouldn't be a body, it would be a mess, and the parts wouldn't combine or function together. We all serve in varying roles and each part we play is important. We aren't to covet others gifts or think of our abilities as menial, rather, making the most of our talents and abilities to serve our God. Pray that God would help you to see your giftedness as a crucial and powerful contributing factor in the body of Christ.
What roles are listed as gifts in the Bible?

"It was he who gave some to be apostles, some to be prophets, some to be evangelists, and some to be pastors and teachers, to prepare God's people for works of service, so that the body of Christ may be built up until we all reach unity in the faith and in the knowledge of the Son of God and become mature, attaining to the whole measure of the fullness of Christ." Ephesians 4:11-13

Most consider the list of spiritual gifts to include the following: prophecy, teaching, encouragement, giving, leadership, mercy, apostleship, prophesy, evangelism, shepherding, wisdom, knowledge, discernment, speaking in tongues, interpretation of tongues, and faith.

What a fascinating realization that God has already appointed us to roles in serving Him. Many are revealed through time, and sometimes we see God giving us new giftedness and abilities in a season when we most need it in our lives. Utilizing our gifts enables us to experience spiritual maturity and growth, uniting us with fellow believers, and seeing more of the character of Christ. Evaluate your life, and ask trusted believers in Christ for their input, on what your spiritual gifts may include. Often we are given more than one. Consider taking a spiritual gift assessment offered through your church.
What impact does using my gifts play in the Kingdom?

"From him the whole body, joined and held together by every supporting ligament, grows and builds itself up in love, as each part does its work." Ephesians 4:16
"The one who calls is faithful and he will do it." 1 Thessalonians 5:24

Using your gifts advances the Kingdom and spreads God's love to world. He only calls you to do what He gives you the ability to do. By using our gifts together we grow in fellowship with one another and develop strong community. Everyone contributes and is mutually encouraged.

Holding back and keeping your giftedness to yourself limits your potential and wastes opportunities to love others and spread the Gospel. If you aren't obedient to the call to use your gift, God will find someone else who will. Raise your hand and accept God's calling. He gave you what you needed when He created you to fulfill that particular kingdom purpose. Why not acknowledge His gifts? So get out and spread His love with the world. More people will be able to hear about and experience God because of your contribution. You are a kingdom worker, appointed by God for His service. Ask God how He can use you more powerfully to advance the Kingdom.
My Future
What kind of future does God want me to have?

"For I know the plans I have for you," declares the Lord, "plans to prosper you and not to harm you, plans to give you a hope and a future." Jeremiah 29:11
"The thief comes only to steal and kill and destroy; I have come that they may have life, and have it to the full." John 10:10

Both of these verses reveal to us that God knows the plans He has for us, that He desires for us to experience an abundant life, and that with Him we can always have hope. The life that Jesus Christ gives us is richer and fuller, more satisfying. It is eternal and it is full of Christ's love, forgiveness and guidance. This does not mean that we will not experience pain, hardship, or suffering. However, it does mean that even through difficult times that the Lord will walk through them with us and will make good even come out of the pain. He never leaves us…ever. He loves you and wants your future to include Him!

Lord Jesus, Thank you that you have plans to prosper me. Help me to remember that You are always with me. You are with me in the good times and with me in the bad times too. Help me to be aware of your presence and help me to be satisfied in You alone. I give my future to you and pray you would open my heart to receive it, open my ears to hear your direction, open my hands to do your work and set my feet to follow the path you place before me. My future is in YOU ALONE. Amen.
What do I do when things don't happen the way I had planned for them to happen?

"Let us fix our eyes on Jesus, the author and perfecter of our faith, who for the joy set before Him endured the cross, scorning its shame, and sat down at the right hand of the throne of God. Consider Him who endured such opposition from sinful men, so that you will not grow weary and lose heart." Hebrews 12:2-3

There are many times in life when things don't happen the way we hoped they would. Here in Hebrews we are told how to handle the disappointment. First, we fix our eyes on Jesus. We focus our heart on Him. We find comfort in knowing that He is the author of our lives and our faith, and there isn't anything that God starts that He doesn't finish. We are encouraged by the truth that we have a God who understands our pain, heartache, and disappointment because He too came to earth and suffered. We have a God who understands us.

As you are confronted with heartache and disappointment, run to Jesus. Share with Him your anger and your hurt. He is big enough to take it, and honestly, He understands. He went through it too. If it helps, find a big rock that you can write on. Write down what is bothering you, and then throw the rock in a pond or bury it in the ground. As you drown the rock tell Jesus that you are giving your disappointment to Him and choosing to focus on His goodness rather than your disappointment. Pray: Jesus, thank you for humbling yourself and coming to live on this earth, experiencing every hurt, pain and disappointment that I do. I know that Your ways are not my ways and Your thoughts are not my thoughts. You have a greater plan and can see the big picture when I can only see part of it. As I go through disappointments in life, help me to focus on You rather than my pain. I love You and trust You. Amen.
How do I prepare now for the future?

"Have nothing to do with godless myths and old wives' tales; rather train yourself to be godly. For physical training is of some value, but godliness has value for all things, holding promise for both the present life and the life to come." I Timothy 4:7-8

The best way to prepare for the future is to be in relationship with the One who knows what the future holds, not just for you but for everyone. Of course, the One we are talking about is Jesus Christ. Seek Him. Spend time in prayer…not just talking to God but also listening as well. Read the Bible and then put it into practice in your own life. Life is way too short to focus on things that won't last so ask the Lord to make you a guy or girl of character.

This week memorize I Timothy 4:7-8 and ask Christ to show you how to train yourself to be godly. Spend at least 5 minutes each day reading His Word. If you don't know where to start, the book of John is a great place. See how Christ lived His life and follow after His example. Pray: Lord Jesus, Help me to follow your example: to follow the Father and to love and serve others well. Give me a hunger and thirst for your Word. Help me to focus more on eternal things rather than things that won't last. In your name, Amen.
How can I know God's will for my life?

"I have considered my ways and have turned my steps to your statutes." Psalm 119:59
"Your Word is a lamp to my feet and a light for my path." Psalm 119:105

If you want to know God's will for your life then you need to be in His Word. We are told in the Bible that "all Scripture is God-breathed" (II Timothy 3:16). It gives us guidance, comfort, encouragement, hope and direction. His basic principles given in the Bible will give you direction for more detailed decisions in your own life: should you date so and so, what college should you go to, how should you spend your time during the summer. Go ahead. Give it a try. I dare you!

Take a week to read through all of Psalm 119. Write down every verse that talks about God's Word. It may use words like statutes, commands, precepts, decrees, etc. Then go back and reflect on all the different blessings that come from God's Word. If you have a certain decision in life that you are trying to find God's answer to, seek out a person who knows Christ well and ask them to point you towards some passage in Scripture that might help you. Then pray and see how God directs your steps.
Does God care about my future?
"Cast all your anxieties on the Lord because He cares for you." I Peter 5:7

Does God care about your future? Well, Scripture tells us that he knows the number of hairs on your head (Matt. 10:30). He also tells us that if He cares as wonderfully for the wildflowers that are here today and gone tomorrow that He will certainly care for you (Matt. 6:30). And not only does He desire to care for us but He also knows all our needs before we even need them (Matt. 6:32). If He cares deeply for you then He also cares deeply about your future. Christ's first desire for your future is that you would know Him personally and that you would live a life with Him. Do you have a personal relationship with Him? Find a time soon to go outside and enjoy the world that God created. Breathe deep. Look at the clouds in the sky. Watch the birds fly. Notice the grass, the trees and the flowers around you. Meditate on the truth that Jesus loves you enough that He died a horrible death for you. Thank Him for all the ways that you see Him caring for you now…some examples might be having food to eat, a roof over your head, friends who listen, family who loves you, etc.

Pray: Jesus, thank you for loving and caring enough about me that you were willing to die on the cross for me. Thank you that you sent the Holy Spirit so that I can always have you with me. Thank you for knowing me intimately to where you even know how many hairs are on my head. Help me to come to you with my hopes and dreams of the future and to seek your direction for my life. Thank you for caring about all of me, including my future plans. Amen.
Partying
What does the Bible say about drinking alcohol?

"The acts of the sinful nature are obvious: sexual immorality, impurity and debauchery; idolatry and witchcraft; hatred, discord, jealousy, fits of rage, selfish ambition, dissensions, factions and envy; drunkenness, orgies, and the like. I warn you, as I did before, that those who live like this will not inherit the kingdom of God. But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self-control. Against such things there is no law." Galatians 5:19-23

The Bible is clear about drinking alcohol or putting dangerous substances, like drugs, into our bodies. Anything which can damage your body or impair your good judgment is wrong in the sight of God. God created you and desires for each person to take care of their body and mind. God knows the impact things like alcohol and drugs make on a persons body and life; they cause disease and harm relationships with those we love.

Remember, the Lord created you and me. He designed our bodies with incredible capabilities to live the life He has given you. When we put harmful things into our bodies we get harmful results. The Lord will fill all of our mind, heart and souls greatest desires if you will let Him. No void or longing is too great for the Lord. He is enough. Read 1 Corinthians, chapter 6 and answer this question posed by Paul, "Do you not know that your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit, who is in you, whom you have received from God?" YOU ARE NOT YOUR OWN.
What is so wrong about getting drunk or drinking to excess? What's the big deal?

"Therefore do not be foolish, but understand what the Lord's will is. Do not get drunk on wine, which leads to debauchery. Instead, be filled with the Spirit." Ephesians 5:17, 18
"Do you not know that your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit, who is in you, whom you have received from God? You are not your own." 1 Corinthians 6:19
These verses emphasize that the Lord wants us to be full of the Spirit and not full of substances that alter our decisions. We are made by God and our body is not our own when we have Christ.

Remember, The Lord created you and me. He designed our bodies with incredible capabilities to live the life He has given you. When we put harmful things into our bodies we get harmful results. The Lord will fill all of our mind, heart and souls greatest desires if we will let Him. No void or longing is too great for the Lord. He is enough.
How can I handle the peer pressure that comes by others when I avoid partying?

"Who is going to harm you if you are eager to do good? But even if you should suffer for what is right, you are blessed. Do not fear what they fear; do not be frightened. But in your hearts set apart Christ as Lord. Always be prepared to give an answer to everyone who asks you to give the reason for the hope that you have. But do this with gentleness and respect, keeping a clear conscience, so that those who speak maliciously against your good behavior in Christ may be ashamed of their slander. It is better, if it is God's will, to suffer for doing good than for doing evil." 1 Peter 3:13-17
Simply put, it is better to do good and suffer than to do evil and suffer. Put your hope in Christ and not in people. God notices your good behavior and you will be blessed.

Always be kind to others and do not judge them, but offer yourself as a living example of how Jesus would want you to act. Sometimes the only Jesus someone knows is the Jesus they see in you. Shine your light for others to see as you go on the path that is right. Chances are you will be admired among others in your same situation lacking your courage and your ability to walk away will inspire them to walk away also. No matter what your peers think, you will be admired by God.
I see my parents partying and feel like if they get drunk and engage in wrong doing, why can't I?

"So we make it our goal to please him, whether we are at home in the body or away from it. For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, that each one may receive what is due him for the things done while in the body, whether good or bad." 2 Corinthians 5:9-10
Our goal should be to please God no matter where we are, what we see or who we trust because we all will appear before HIS judgment.

It is really a question of judgment. Parents are our role models, but they are not perfect, just as no one is perfect. Ultimately, our greatest role model is Christ because he was the only perfect man and our fate is in HIS hands. He asks us to make it a goal to please HIM. When you use good judgment and stray from temptations that bring harm, like drugs, alcohol, and sex, your final judgment will be better off having resisted the urge to party.
My life is out of control and temptations to get drunk and do bad things are all about me; where is there help?

"So, if you think you are standing firm, be careful that you don't fall! No temptation has seized you except what is common to man. And God is faithful; he will not let you be tempted beyond what you can bear. But when you are tempted, he will also provide a way out so that you can stand up under it." 1 Corinthians 10:12-13
Even people that are not "out of control" feel tempted according to the word of the Lord. And HE will not let you be tempted beyond what you can bear.

Where is your help? Jesus is the answer. There will be difficult situations even when you are doing what is right, but God is faithful and he will give you strength to stand and not fall. Pray: Give me strength in my weakness. Keep me from doing bad things when it seems I cannot help myself. Be my help Jesus. I am entrusting you to care for me. I will increase my faith believing you will lift me from the pits of my despair. In Jesus' name, AMEN.
Prayer
How often/when should I pray?
"Pray continually" 1 Thessalonians 5:17

God doesn't want us to stop doing everything and always be in our room on our knees praying. He wants our life to be a life that is always aware of Him and connected to Him. So prayer should be like breathing, wherever we go, we are aware of Him and in communication with Him.

Who in your life are you closest with? How often do you talk and/or text them? The point is this- You communicate with them regularly. God is everywhere and knows you (Psalm 139:1-18, Matthew 10:30). Start talking to God regularly; wherever you go, whatever you're doing. You don't have to get on your knees, close your eyes, and fold your hands together. You can just talk to him; even in your head without talking out loud. Watch a sunset or sunrise and tell Him how beautiful His creation is. Think about what you're thankful for and thank Him. He's is always there, you can always talk to Him (and He wants you to). Anytime and anywhere!
Does God speak to me in prayer? How do I know it's Him?
"…but in these last days he has spoken to us by his Son, whom he appointed heir of all things, and through whom he made the universe." Hebrews 1:2

Don't get hung up by the phrase "last days", this refers to the time after Jesus' resurrection and ascent to Heaven, which means "last days" is right now, TODAY. So, today God has spoken to us. But how does He speak? By his Son, Jesus! You may have heard the old phrase WWJD, "What Would Jesus Do", but it is more than that, it's "What would Jesus do AND THINK". We should have the same attitude as Jesus. We know God speaks to us when we hear the same words that come from the Bible.

You may hear a small, still voice tell you, "Ashley, go help that lady with her groceries" or, "Connor, help your little brother with his homework", and you find those words in the Bible phrased as "love your neighbor as yourself" (Matthew 22:39) and this Bible verse makes the voices true. Be warned, many people may claim to have heard from God. But if it goes AGAINST what the Bible says, then they are a LIAR. God does not contradict Himself. Pray- Lord, since you want me to love others, show me what I can do for one of my family members or friends. Sit and wait for God to speak. When He does- Go do what He said to do- WWJD!
If God knows everything, why pray? Can I change God's mind?
"The LORD replied, I have forgiven them, as you asked." Numbers 14:20

In this story God was going to do one thing but doesn't, why? Because Moses asked him not to! "The prayer of a righteous man is powerful and effective" according to James 5:16. Righteous means right standing with God. And we know that all who have faith in Jesus Christ are righteous (Romans 3:22). So, if you have faith in Christ, your prayer is powerful and effective. So which is it? Is God all-knowing or can I change His mind? The answer is YES to both!

God is bigger than we think or can imagine He is. He can do anything, NOTHING is IMPOSSIBLE! But it is better to understand and have a relationship with God, rather than Him being our everyday Santa Clause (if He did bring us stuff non-stop that would make God our servant, and us His master, which is a ridiculous idea). Would you rather God give you everything you are asking for today and then never talk to you or give you anything ever again? Or would you rather be in constant contact and relationship with God, where when you pray He says "yes", other times He says "no", and sometimes He says "wait"? The second option is much better don't you think? Pray to understand God and the goodness of His commands. Try and put yourself in God's "shoes". Then pray for what is on your heart.
Does prayer help?
"Trust in the LORD with all your heart and lean not on your own understanding" Proverbs 3:5

He is God and we are not, but He cares about us. He even delights in us (Psalm 18:19). When we pray it is our way of showing we rely on Him and not ourselves, or anyone or anything of this world. Prayer does many things. One thing it does is bring a peace that goes beyond understanding (Philippians 4:6-7). Prayer is also how we confess our sins, which helps us acknowledge our need for Him.

Many times we don't pray, because we think we don't need to; this is a lie. We think we have everything under control, but it's an illusion. Prayer helps us recognize that we are not in control. God, the loving Father, Creator of all things, is in control. If you need peace, then in Jesus' name, pray for peace (Philippians 4:6-7). If you need help trusting God, then have a conversation with God about it and ask Him for help to do what Proverbs 3:5 says.
How Do I Pray?

"But when you pray, go into your room, close the door and pray to your Father, who is unseen. Then your Father, who sees what is done in secret, will reward you. And do not keep on babbling like pagans, for they think they will be heard because of their many words. Do not be like them for your Father knows what you need before you ask him." Matthew 6:6-8

Jesus was frustrated with the hypocrites that stood proud praying for all to hear for their own attention. Prayer is between you and the Lord. The reward is your relationship with Him, not the attention of others. Praying in prayer groups aloud and for one another is perfectly fine and powerful in agreement with other believers. Simple words, short and sweet are fine ways to pray too. God knows what you need before you ask him. So pray knowing you are a sinner in need of prayer (Romans 3:23), pray believing you will receive (Matthew 21:22) and pray in Jesus name (John 16:23). Be honest with God, you're not going to tell him anything He doesn't know. Later in this passage Jesus tells you how to pray…

WWJP/What would Jesus pray? "Our Father in heaven, hallowed be your name, your kingdom come, your will be done on earth as it is in heaven. Give us today our daily bread. Forgive us our debts, as we also have forgiven our debtors. And lead us not into temptation, but deliver us from the evil one." Amen Check out how Jesus said to pray in Luke 11:1-13 too. You can even try and say them in your own words because it is all about being REAL.
Questioning
I feel alone and afraid, no one can help me. What do I do?

"Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls. For my yoke is easy and my burden is light." Matthew 11:29

Jesus loves you and wants you to come to him. He is gentle, humble and peace itself. He gave His life so that all who are hurting might find rest in Him. Close your eyes and imagine him standing open arms with pierced hands stretched forth longing to embrace you. Go on, what are you waiting for, run to him and find your peace.

Find time this week to read Isaiah 43:1-5, and answer the following questions: What does God say you belong to? Who has called you? How does it make you feel that He has pursued a relationship with you? What difficulties does the Lord say He will walk through with you in these verses? Think about a difficult time you have had. How did God show you He was there with you? In verse 4, how does God describe you? Why, in verse 5, does God tell us not to be afraid?
Lord Jesus, Help me to remember that You are always with me. You are with me in the good times and with me in the bad times too. Help me to be aware of your presence and help me to be satisfied in You alone. Amen.
Why do bad things happen to good people?
"I have told you these things, so that in me you may have peace. In the world you will have trouble. But take heart! I have overcome the world." John 16:33

Jesus was speaking to the disciples before he was about to leave them to face his death knowing they would be without him. Jesus was good. Not only was he good, he was perfect. Still, something really bad happened to him. It wasn't just bad, it was horrible. He was the Son of God; yet, he was misjudged, abused, beaten and put to death.

God doesn't promise life will be easy. Actually he says "you will have trouble", but keep the faith, realizing Jesus took the ultimate punishment for you. So when this world tries to beat you down, HE has your back all the way to the end. Your reward comes as you stand faithful in this world, proclaiming Christ and receiving eternal life in Heaven.
Why did Jesus have to die if God can do all things?

"Since the children have flesh and blood he too shared in their humanity so that by his death he might destroy him who holds the power of death-that is, the devil-and free those who all their lives were held in slavery by their fear of death. For surely it is not angels he helps, but Abraham's descendants. For this reason he had to be made like his brothers in every way, in order that he might become a merciful and faithful high priest in service to God, and that he might make atonement for the sins of the people. Because he himself suffered when he was tempted, he is able to help those who are being tempted." Hebrews 2:14-18

This is one of the most perplexing questions we face as Christians. Jesus is our brother as a descendant of Abraham as are we. He took the sting of death in our place as a sacrifice for our sins that started back in the Garden of Eden. God gave us free will and we failed to do what was right and fell to the temptations of Satan. So God allowed his flesh and blood SON to pay for our flesh and blood...covering us with his grace. The blood of Jesus covers us, protects us and completes us!

The ways of God are beyond our comprehension and we try to fit our understanding in terms to which we can relate. Relating to God is virtually impossible, but relating to Jesus comes easier because he was a person. God can do all things and he decides all things. And even though the decision God made to allow his son to suffer seems unjustifiable, HE alone is the justifier of our souls for "my thoughts are not your thoughts, neither your ways my ways, " declares the Lord. Pray: God thank you for having mercy on my soul and keeping me from the sting of death. My soul is saved because you forgave. Jesus your blood was shed for me and that is all I need to know. I love you so! AMEN
What is the Holy Spirit?

"If you love me, you will obey what I command. And I will ask the Father, and he will give you another Counselor to be with you forever-the Spirit of Truth." John 14:15-16
"But the Counselor, the Holy Spirit, whom the Father will send in my name, will teach you all things and will remind you of everything I have said to you. Peace I leave with you; my peace I give you." John 14:26
"As for you, the anointing you received from him remains in you, and you do not need anyone to teach you. But as his anointing teaches you about all things and as that anointing is real, not counterfeit…"1 John 2:27
"The Spirit searches all things, even the deep things of God. For who among men knows the thoughts of a man except the man's spirit within him? In the same way no one knows the thoughts of God except the Spirit of God. We have not received the spirit of the world but the Spirit who is from God…" 1 Corinthians 2:10-12
"So live by the Spirit, and you will not gratify the desires of the sinful nature." Galatians 5:16

The Holy Spirit was sent by God when Jesus died and went to heaven. He left the Spirit here for us. His instructions were for us to live by the Spirit. The Holy Spirit searches all, knows all and gives all truth. It is our counselor, teacher, anointing, and peace.
Recognize the power of the Holy Spirit. Together God the Father, Jesus the Son and The Holy Spirit make the Trinity. The God head three in one.
Why is having money considered evil or wrong according to God?

Jesus said to him, "If you want to be perfect, go, sell your possessions and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow me." When the young man heard this, he went away sad, because he had great wealth. Then Jesus said to His disciples, "I tell you the truth, it is hard for a rich man to enter the kingdom of heaven. Again I tell you, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle, than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God." When the disciples heard this, they were greatly astonished and asked, "Who then can be saved?" Jesus looked at them and said, "With man this is impossible, but with God all things are possible." Matthew 19:21-26

The rich man in this story was inquiring about what good thing he could do to have eternal life. Jesus told him there was only One who was good and the man persisted. Jesus replied keep the commandments. The man replied I have kept them. The above passage was Jesus' last response to the rich man.

God wants to prosper us and bless us. Money itself is not the problem, it is the control it has over people. The man was sad because he liked his money and didn't want to part with it. We have strong emotional responses to money. We need money to live, but when we live to possess money, we have our priorities wrong. Money might seem to save us here on earth by giving us food, shelter, transportation, education, etc, but the only one who can save us is God. The power money has over us is a temptation that if we are not careful can keep us from the kingdom of heaven. Give God his portion by tithing and planting seed into his purpose and allow him to guide your finances.
Sad
I am sad, but as a Christian shouldn't I have joy?
"A righteous man may have many troubles, but the Lord delivers him from them all…" Psalm 34:19
You can be the walking in righteousness with the Lord and still be sad. The good news is that He has your back. He will deliver or carry your sadness.

Jesus was the perfect man walking in righteousness and yet he wept. He wept over the death of his friend Lazarus. He wept over the city of Jerusalem. He wept in sadness. Just because you have the joy of Christ doesn't mean you are immune to sadness. Maybe you just need a good dose of Jesus to boost your immunities!
How can I move past my sorrow?

"Brothers, I do not consider myself yet to have taken hold of it. But one thing I do: Forgetting what is behind and straining toward what is ahead. I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus." Philippians 3:13-14

Take one step closer to the goal. Just put one foot in front of the other until you are past the sorrow looking back to a speck that used to be your sorrow, but now is unrecognizable because you have gone the distance with Christ carrying you and cheering you along the way.

Nike ads tell us to "just do it". Let go and just do it…release the grief to God before it takes an unhealthy hold on you. Don't carry this burden to the grave. Christ came to set us free from bondage like grief, depression, sadness. Your feelings and thoughts not bowed to the truth of Christ will become the lies of Satan and will handcuff you to loneliness. Resist in the name of Jesus. He bore your grief on the cross. Gladness and joy are meant to be yours!
What does the Bible say about sadness?
"A happy heart makes the face cheerful but heartache crushes the spirit. The discerning heart seeks knowledge, but the mouth of a fool feeds on folly." Proverbs 15:13-14

In these verses we find a comparison between a merry heart and a sorrowful heart. The condition of a man's heart is told by his facial appearance. Sadness crushes the spirit and makes the heart ache. The Bible tells us many things about sorrow. Here we learn that sadness invades us physically as well as emotionally.

We can all relate to a friend asking us "What is wrong?" When we are sad we show it on our face. Our eyes lose their sparkle and our smile disappears. Sometimes our chest will actually hurt from the loss of something or someone dear to us, creating literally a heart ache. Do you know someone who has lost their smile? Maybe it is you. Look to Jesus to give you back your smile and your sparkle. Share His joy with those around you suffering from a crushed spirit.
What is God doing when I am sad?

"Rejoice with those who rejoice; mourn with those who mourn." Romans 12:15
"Therefore he is able to save completely those who come to God through him, because he always lives to intercede for them." Hebrews 7:25
"But he said to me, "My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness." " 2 Corinthians 12:9-10
According to these scriptures, God is grieving with us, praying for us and carrying us through the sadness.

Jesus said in John 15:15 that He calls us friend. We have a friend, in addition to a Father and a Savior. Your sadness is His sadness and like a good friend he will be sad with you, pray for you and be strong for you when you are weak.
Say aloud: I am a friend of God! Yes, He calls me friend!
What can I look forward to when I am so sad?

"…and provide for those who grieve in Zion to bestow on them a crown of beauty instead of ashes, the oil of gladness instead of mourning, and a garment of praise instead of a spirit of despair. They will be called oaks of righteousness, a planting of the Lord for the display of his splendor." Isaiah 61:3

God used the prophet Isaiah to speak words of encouragement from Heaven on high. Back in Biblical days, people would put on sackcloth and ashes to symbolize their grief and mourning. The Lord says you can look forward to a day very soon when you will be wearing a beautiful crown. You will be full of gladness that saturates your person like oil and dressed in the finest garment of thanksgiving for He will deliver you from these days of sadness.

Sadness comes in many different forms. Perhaps you are grieving the loss of a loved one, a relationship or a missed opportunity. Whatever form it takes it can be overwhelming and sometimes can literally make you hopeless. Practical ways to gain your joy back are to force yourself to be in the presence of the Lord by going to church, reading the word of God, posting uplifting verses in your room or car, speaking to a trusted friend or seeking Christian counseling. (See Hope Topic on App)
Jesus, deliver me from the pits of despair and wrap your everlasting arms about me taking me to higher ground. I need you more than ever. Please replace my sorrow with joy and my tears with laughter. Only you have the power to take this anguish from me. I believe you are more than able and I am yours to mend back to wholeness. I give you my mind, body and soul. In your precious name, AMEN
